timeline.message:
Introduce autoscaling policies

This commit is the first in a series of commits that introduces
autoscaling policies, and APIs for working with them. For now, we
introduce the basic infrastructure, and a single API for putting an
autoscaling policy. We will follow in rapid succession with APIs for
getting, and deleting autoscaling policies.
Revert inadvertent change to test runs

timeline.bodyText: I wonder if this needs to be a sorted map or if a plain map could work out? I think decisions should work the same regardless, favoring up over down over no scale.
timeline.author: henningandersen

replies.bodyText: I prefer sorted maps because it gives consistent and predictable output. It's not necessary, it's just a preference.
replies.author: jasontedor

timeline.author: henningandersen
henningandersen

timeline.bodyText:
At the REST layer, we use a map from decider name to decider details, whereas here we use a list. I think we should align the two.
I find it hard to imagine using the same decider twice in a single policy. The only case I can think of is a compound decider that decides based on the result of other more basic deciders, like "only scale up if needed by all inner deciders" or "allow scale down if one of these deciders allow it".
I think I prefer the map style and not allowing such compound deciders in the future.
timeline.author: henningandersen

replies.bodyText: I changed this to a map.
replies.author: jasontedor

timeline.bodyText: Looking at other mutate functions, they seem to be more sure of returning an unequal instance. I guess it is very unlikely with 8 random chars, but think it would be more clear if we append something to the existing name instead?
timeline.author: henningandersen

timeline.bodyText: Depending on the list vs map discussion (see other comment), we could maybe add a random number of always deciders here.
timeline.author: henningandersen

timeline.bodyText: I think we write the policy name twice on the stream, both here and in AutoscalingPolicy.writeTo. It looks easy to avoid and if so, I would prefer that. Otherwise, it is not a big deal.
timeline.author: henningandersen
henningandersen

timeline.bodyText: I think this could be private too? The usage in Autoscaling could use the AutoscalingMetadata.parse method instead.

timeline.bodyText: It would be weird to have a policy with no deciders (and I think AutoscalingDecisions require at least one anyway). Maybe we should validate that here?
timeline.author: henningandersen

replies.bodyText: I think we can add validation for this later.

replies.bodyText:
Ouch, great catch. This should not be working, and I can tell you why it is, because there's a horrible bug in the assertion! The bug is:
assertThat(beforeState.custom(AutoscalingMetadata.NAME), sameInstance(afterState.custom(AutoscalingMetadata.NAME)))

should be
assertThat(beforeState.metadata().custom(AutoscalingMetadata.NAME), sameInstance(afterState.metadata().custom(AutoscalingMetadata.NAME)))

Oops!
Great catch though.
